author: By Patrick Kingsley and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden and Netanyahu Meet to Try to Soothe Tensions, With Some Success
description: The president put aside his frustrations with the Israeli prime minister over his “extremist” government to focus on issues of mutual interest, like Iran and Saudi Arabia.
content: For the first time since Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel returned to office last December, he and President Biden met face to face on Wednesday in a session that both soothed and aggravated tensions between the leaders and demonstrated Mr. Biden’s wider commitment to Israeli security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Lawyers for Fake Trump Electors Hint at Defense Strategy in Georgia Case
description: The details came at a hearing on whether the three electors, co-defendants of Donald J. Trump in an election interference case, could have their cases moved to federal court.
content: Lawyers for three Georgia Republicans charged in a racketeering indictment for casting false Electoral College votes for former President Donald J. Trump offered a glimpse of their defense strategy on Wednesday, telling a federal judge that they submitted the votes as part of their “duty” under federal law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Lying in Comedy Isn’t Always Wrong, but Hasan Minhaj Crossed a Line
description: The stand-up’s penchant for making up stories goes beyond embellishment. When real people and real stakes are involved, a different standard applies.
content: When I first heard that The New Yorker had published an exposé on the veracity of the stand-up comedy of Hasan Minhaj, I rolled my eyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña, Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Crowley
title: Zelensky Tells U.N. Security Council It’s Useless While Russia Has a Veto
description: The Ukrainian president joined many world leaders in calling for changes at the Security Council, where five permanent members wield veto power — a high barrier to taking action.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, denouncing Russia’s “unprovoked aggression,” told the United Nations Security Council on Wednesday that if it did not break the grip of Russian veto power, it would be powerless to resolve conflicts around the world, adding his voice to the rising calls to overhaul how the body works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: The Litany of #MeToo News Continues. Is anything really changing?
description: It can appear as though society is no closer to a future in which women can go about their ordinary lives without being harassed, assaulted and coerced into silence.
content: The endless, relentless eruptions of sexual abuse and harassment scandals can sometimes seem like a particularly grim form of Zeno’s dichotomy paradox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Trajal Harrell’s Dance Card Is Full
description: The American choreographer has 46 engagements this year, including a monthslong retrospective of his work in Paris. But he is making plans for a “second act” away from the dance world.
content: The American choreographer Trajal Harrell has a rule. Though he lives between Switzerland and Greece, he tries to make it home to Douglas, Ga., to visit his mother every three months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Michael Bloomberg Dials Up a War on Plastics
description: The former New York City mayor is spending some of his wealth to try to block the construction of petrochemical plants. But this fight may be tougher than his earlier efforts to close coal-burning power plants.
content: Michael Bloomberg is many things: former New York City mayor, founder of a financial data company, failed presidential candidate and the 11th richest man in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: A Hand Up
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Sheet-Pan Vegetarian Dinner Can’t Get Much Simpler
description: This colorful meal from Melissa Clark, full of chickpeas and peppers, comes together in two steps — no charring over an open flame required.
content: There’s a time-honored technique for roasting bell peppers. This recipe isn’t it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Sunak Weakens U.K. Climate Targets as Election Approaches
description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said he would delay a ban on the sale of new gas- and diesel-only cars, among other measures, sparking division in his own party.
content: After years of claiming leadership in the international fight against climate change, Britain’s government on Wednesday gambled on an abrupt change of course, weakening key environmental pledges and promising lower costs for Britons who will soon be asked to vote in a general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: New York City Loses Contentious Bid for Cricket Stadium to Long Island
description: The Adams administration hoped to place a 34,000-seat stadium in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, but its bid was met with criticism over the plan to lose public space to a private tournament.
content: A contentious plan backed by Mayor Eric Adams for the International Cricket Council to build a temporary, 34,000-seat stadium in a Bronx park is dead, following heated opposition from local elected officials and some amateur cricket players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nic Stone
title: 6 Great Y.A. Books That Open Up Conversations About Teen Mental Health
description: Nic Stone, the author of “Dear Martin,” “Chaos Theory” and more, recommends some of her favorite young adult books about mental health.
content: I was 14 years old when I experienced my first mental health crisis. Things were tricky at home, and I was deeply overwhelmed with emotions that I didn’t have the space or language to express. As a result, I developed an anxiety disorder. Anxiety begot depression, and there came a night when I just didn’t want to deal anymore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Winchester
title: Not All Heroes Wear Capes. Some Prefer Lab Coats.
description: In “Foreign Bodies,” Simon Schama studies pandemics past and present, and how much — and little — we have learned.
content: The appearance of yet another enthusiastic and erudite history from Simon Schama is an event always to be welcomed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Miller
title: Being 13 Is Hard. Being a Parent Brings It All Back.
description: A mom’s view of raising a young teen in 2023.
content: Jancee Dunn is off this week. I’m an editor at Well, filling in to tell you about a special project we’ve just published.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Ex-Husband Was a Cheater. Should I Tell My Kids the Truth?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to disclose the intimate details of a divorce.
content: Four years ago, my husband of nine years asked me for a divorce in a doomed couples-therapy session. While I was devastated and committed to continue working on our differences, he was convinced we had tried hard enough. We told our school-aged children that we were getting divorced. He moved out into a rented apartment within the next two months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter, Aida Alami and Nariman El-Mofty
title: Navigating a Perilous Mountain Pass After a Devastating Earthquake
description: A stretch of lonely road across Morocco’s Atlas Mountains has long been known for its stunning views and perilous turns. After the earthquake, it became a lifeline for dozens of destroyed villages.
content: Climbing up around 7,000 feet over the Atlas Mountains, the road through the Tizi N’Test pass bends impossibly around cliff edges, expands and pinches uncomfortably to a single fragile track and creeps under jagged rocky outcrops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Four-Ingredient Nutella Brownies With a Five-Minute Prep Time
description: Because Wednesday.
content: I nearly always end this newsletter with a dessert, as my sweet tooth demands, but sometimes you have to start off with a treat. And Jessie Sheehan’s Nutella brownies demand a spot right at the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Volodymyr Zelensky at the U.N.
content: Speaking at an annual gathering of world leaders at the U.N. General Assembly, Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, presented Russia’s invasion as a worldwide threat that would not stop at the borders of Ukraine. He added that Russia was weaponizing essentials like food and energy “not only against our country, but against all of yours, as well.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: What Social Media Does to the Teen Brain
description: Despite the headlines, the impact of social apps on adolescent mental health isn’t so clear.
content: Every generation has its moral panic and for Gen Z — teenagers today — it is, undoubtedly, social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Hope and Despair on a Boiling Planet
description: As efforts to control climate change are on the rise across the globe, the challenges are steeper than ever.
content: On any given day, there is good reason to be both exceedingly optimistic about the progress being made to combat climate change, and also deeply concerned about the threats presented by a rapidly warming planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Ronna McDaniel Gets the Trump Treatment
description: Behold the embarrassment of Ronna McDaniel.
content: Donald Trump claims to be the best, most or first in countless laughable ways, but there’s one endeavor at which he really is peerless: Nobody dishes out humiliation in such heaping, merciless measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: A Sotheby’s Sale of Mug Shots, I.D. Badges and Early Kodak Prints
description: The auction house is offering an eclectic collection from Pier 24 Photography, including anonymous snapshots of Lucky Luciano and 1880s baseball players.
content: Pier 24 Photography made its debut in 2010 on the San Francisco waterfront, the creation of a former investment banker, Andrew Pilara. Since then, the exhibition space has staged highly regarded photography shows, mostly drawn from the founder’s wide-ranging collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Here Are the Five Republicans Who Have Defied McCarthy on Spending
description: The defectors broke with their party to block a Pentagon spending bill from being debated in the House. Their stances reflect deep G.O.P. divisions pushing the government toward a shutdown.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s latest embarrassing setback unfolded on the House floor on Tuesday, when five rebel Republicans took the rare step of breaking with their party to block a Pentagon spending bill from coming to the floor for a vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Rising Frustration Over the Homelessness Crisis in Sacramento
description: The county district attorney sued the City of Sacramento for what he says is lax enforcement of laws that could help stem its homelessness problem.
content: About 171,000 people living in California are homeless, a total that, stunningly, accounts for nearly one-third of all the homeless people in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Boston College Suspends Swimming and Diving Teams Over Hazing
description: The indefinite suspension was announced on Wednesday, days before the teams were to begin their seasons.
content: Boston College said on Wednesday that it had suspended its swimming and diving program indefinitely after university officials learned about hazing within the teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: U.K. Inflation Rate Slips Lower for Third Straight Month
description: Prices rose at an annual rate of 6.7 percent in August. A rise in energy costs was offset by a slower increase in food prices.
content: Inflation in Britain slowed for a third consecutive month in August, unexpectedly continuing its downward trend despite a jump in fuel prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen
title: No, I Don’t Want to Go for a Walk With You
description: Walking is a solo activity, and no one is going to convince me otherwise.
content: A new form of social tyranny has broken out. Opposition to it seems churlish and unsporting. Refusal risks offense. Other than actual or feigned injury, or bad weather, there is truly no escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Aims for Soft Landing With a Rate Pause and a Pledge to Move ‘Carefully’
description: Central bankers held rates steady at 5.25 to 5.5 percent, and forecast that they could still make a final quarter-point-rate move this year.
content: Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged on Wednesday and released a roundly optimistic set of economic forecasts that showed inflation fading more swiftly this year even with a solidly growing economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russell Janzen
title: On Leaving the Life of the Body: A Dancer Reports
description: “I know that I am about to give up one of my primary ways of being me,” Russell Janzen writes about retiring from New York City Ballet after 16 years.
content: It is one of my last ballet classes as a professional dancer. Halfway through barre we do rond de jambes — an exercise in which you paint half circles on the floor with your toes. The teacher, Gonzalo Garcia, sets a combination that sweeps back and forth as we transfer our weight from one foot to the next, our arms swinging to amplify our movements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Top Studio Executives Join Writers’ Strike Negotiations
description: The stalemate is in its fifth month, and talks between the union and the Hollywood studios resumed for the first time since August.
content: Negotiations between the Hollywood writers’ union and the major entertainment companies resumed on Wednesday after a month, with top executives joining the talks for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Abortion Rights Group Sees Mission Beyond ‘Pro-Choice,’ So It Has a New Name
description: NARAL Pro-Choice America is now Reproductive Freedom for All, as the post-Roe landscape reshapes the policy fights over abortion access.
content: NARAL Pro-Choice America, one of the country’s largest advocacy groups for abortion rights, announced on Wednesday that it had changed its name, a switch that illustrates the issue’s shifting politics after the Supreme Court overturned federal abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Robert Klane, Writer of ‘Weekend at Bernie’s,’ Dies at 81
description: He also adapted his best-known novel, “Where’s Poppa?,” into the script for a raw Carl Reiner comedy and directed the disco movie “Thank God It’s Friday.”
content: Robert Klane, a comic novelist, screenwriter and filmmaker with a taste for gleeful vulgarity who wrote the screenplay for “Weekend at Bernie's,” the 1989 cult film about two young insurance company employees who create the illusion that their murdered boss is still alive, died on Aug. 29 at his home in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Rosen
title: Floods, Winds and Temperature Extremes Challenge Rail Lines
description: The environmental risks to railroads are rising, but the measures to reduce the danger will be costly.
content: The 351-mile LOSSAN rail corridor in Southern California, the second busiest in the United States, is under siege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korean Police Accuse 17 U.S. Soldiers of Drug Crimes
description: The soldiers distributed or used synthetic marijuana brought onto an Army base through the military postal service, according to the police.
content: The police in South Korea on Wednesday accused 17 American soldiers and five other people of distributing or using synthetic marijuana that had been brought into the country through the U.S. military’s postal service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy and Derek Arthur
title: What the Autoworkers’ ‘Audacious’ Demands Could Mean for Workers in America
description: “The long, hot summer of labor” is turning into the “hot fall of labor.”
content: The United Auto Workers are on strike, and their demands are “audacious,” according to the union’s own president. They include, among other things, an almost 40 percent pay increase over four years and a 32-hour workweek.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Federal Judge, 96, Is Suspended Amid Concerns About Her Mental Fitness
description: Judge Pauline Newman has denied accusations that she is unable to perform the duties of her job and has challenged an investigation into her cognitive state.
content: Judge Pauline Newman’s colleagues on a federal appeals court in Washington have called her “the heroine of the patent system” and “the most beloved colleague on our court.” But on Wednesday, they also told Judge Newman, 96, that she had been suspended amid growing concerns about her mental fitness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Young Voters Are Frustrated. They’re Staying Engaged ‘Out of Sheer Self-Defense.’
description: It’s a sad state of affairs that our current political system starves young people of hope and optimism.
content: A Pew Research Center report released this week called Americans’ views of our politics “dismal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: He Dissected Trump. Now Michael Wolff Performs an Autopsy on Fox News.
description: In “The Fall,” Wolff predicts the collapse of Rupert Murdoch’s cable network and recounts the recent tumult there through a barrage of fuzzily sourced trash talk.
content: Michael Wolff’s new book is a chronicle of very recent events that starts with something that hasn’t happened yet: the death of Rupert Murdoch, who as of this writing is 92 and very much alive. A prologue in the form of a deadpan mock obituary — by far the most sober and judicious stretch of pages in this cornucopia of innuendo and convoluted prose — sets up a headlong tumble through 18 months of uncertainty and upheaval at Fox News and among its custodians in the Murdoch family. A story of chaotic corporate stewardship and generational conflict unfolds in the shadow of a looming actuarial certainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski
title: Azerbaijan Reclaims Armenian Enclave, Shifting Region’s Political Dynamics
description: Pro-Armenian leaders in the breakaway region of Nagorno-Karabakh appeared to have surrendered to Azerbaijan’s demands.
content: Azerbaijan said on Wednesday that it had restored full control over a breakaway Armenian enclave, a development that could create thousands of new refugees and spell the end of decades of Armenian efforts to assert sovereignty in the mountainous Caucasus region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Subtle Change for Biden
description: How the president talks about the world is changing.
content: President Biden has made it a signature phrase of his administration: The world is engaged in “a battle between democracy and autocracy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: How Often Do Women Think About … ?
description: Unlike men, they definitely aren’t thinking about the Roman Empire. Their ex-best friends, space aliens and Princess Diana are more likely to be on the list.
content: Natasha Vaynblat, a stand-up comedian, has had aliens on her mind for the last week. Consuming her, in fact, she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan and Ed Shanahan
title: Anger Erupts as Rabbis Who Started Fatal Nursing Home Fire Avoid Jail
description: The March 2021 fire, which began with a pre-Passover cleansing of the home’s kitchen and ovens, killed a resident and a firefighter.
content: Tensions ran high in a Rockland County, N.Y., courtroom on Wednesday as two rabbis who have admitted to recklessly starting a deadly fire at an assisted living home were spared jail time under a plea agreement with prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford Reaches a Labor Deal in Canada as U.S. Talks Inch Along
description: The United Auto Workers union is threatening to expand strikes on Friday if it does not make significant progress in talks with General Motors, Ford and Stellantis.
content: Negotiations between each of the three large U.S. automakers and the United Auto Workers union remain far from being resolved, but one of the companies — Ford Motor — has averted a second strike in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Google Says Switching Away From Its Search Engine Is Easy. It’s Not.
description: Google says a change takes just a few steps, but a panel of designers found otherwise. The issue is at the heart of a federal antitrust trial.
content: Imagine if every time you went to the supermarket, your shopping cart came loaded with the same box of cereal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael Simon Johnson, Summer Thomad, Carlos Prieto, Devon Taylor, Lisa Chow, Will Reid, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Is College Worth It?
description: The new economics of higher education make going to college a risky bet.
content: New research and polling show that more and more Americans now doubt a previously unquestioned fact of U.S. life — that going to college is worth it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Climate Experts Weigh In on Obstacles, Priorities and Hope
description: Participants in The New York Times Climate Forward event sum up their views on the response to the crisis — and the challenges for young people.
content: The urgent need to address the conditions that are causing climate change — and to lessen the impact as temperatures climb and environmental catastrophes mount — has drawn widespread engagement from governments, politicians, industries, scientists, advocacy groups and concerned citizens. Leaders from many of the fields will be speaking, presenting and discussing their efforts at The New York Times Climate Forward event in New York on Thursday. We asked a sampling of participants to reply in advance to three questions about the state of the response to the environmental challenges. Their answers, which have been edited and condensed, are included here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Michael Leva, Who Found Fashion Fame Early, Is Dead at 62
description: Known for sophisticated and wearable clothes, he was among a crop of young designers celebrated in the late 1980s. He went on to consult for fashion companies.
content: Michael Leva, who was a celebrated young fashion designer on the verge of national prominence, then pivoted to a career as a fashion executive and branding consultant, died on Sept. 14 in Providence, R.I. He was 62.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: As City Ballet Celebrates Its 75th, Dancers (Hundreds) Take a Bow
description: New York City Ballet kicked off its 75th anniversary season with George Balanchine’s full-length triptych “Jewels” and a poignant onstage tribute.
content: George Balanchine, by his own admission, always admired jewels, a quality he attributed to his Georgian roots. “I like the color of gems, the beauty of stones,” he wrote in “101 Stories of the Great Ballets.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: U.K. Police Officer to Be Charged With Murder in Shooting of Black Man
description: Investigators say the officer killed Chris Kaba, 24, in London last year. The charge announcement is another blow to a police force accused of racism and misogyny.
content: British prosecutors announced a murder charge on Wednesday for a police officer accused of fatally shooting a Black man in south London last year during a botched arrest operation, a rare move in a case that has prompted calls for greater police accountability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak
title: At a Summit on Climate Ambition, the U.S. and China End Up on the B List
description: The world’s two biggest polluters were not invited to speak at a United Nations meeting designed to highlight effective action against warming.
content: The United Nations’ secretary general, António Guterres, convened a special summit on Wednesday in New York City designed to highlight the efforts of the most ambitious global leaders on climate policy — and to implicitly shame those who are dragging their feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gage Daughdrill
title: Six Emerging Brands to Know This Season
description: From a line that draws on Jamaican craft traditions to a buzzy British designer making latex pants, these are the labels to watch this fashion month.
content: Diotima
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Angel
title: Where the Crowds Are Gulls and Crabs
description: On Block Island, a tiny dot off the New England coast, birders and other nature lovers can find beauty and solitude in 2,500 acres of ponds, dunes and marshes.
content: Had I stepped into a scene from “Planet of the Gulls”? The sky resonated with the sound of flapping wings, and groups of the birds shrieked and stalked among the shrubs on a rocky beach at Block Island National Wildlife Refuge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Ancient Logs Offer Earliest Example of Human Woodworking
description: Scientists have unearthed logs in Africa that are nearly a half-million years old, the remnants of large wooden structures crafted by our early ancestors.
content: Nearly half a million years ago, humans in Africa were assembling wood into large structures, according to a study published Wednesday that describes notched and tapered logs buried under sand in Zambia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: The United Auto Workers Is Overplaying Its Hand, Risking Our Economy and the Election
description: Autoworkers want, and deserve, a big raise. But they are asking for too much.
content: The United Auto Workers has taken to the picket lines in a particularly acrimonious strike, targeting, for the first time, all three of the big Detroit automakers simultaneously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: As the Climate Changes, Pressure Is Growing to Make Buildings More Efficient
description: Governments are weighing both regulations and incentives to cut emissions and energy use in new construction.
content: Charlotte the child is active: running, playing, giggling while she rides her bike. But her namesake, Charlotte the condo building, is passive. Its airtight rooms use a fraction of the energy required by the buildings around it, staying cool in the summer and warm in the winter, while light-soaked and quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sonia Shah
title: The Animals Are Talking. What Does It Mean?
description: Language was long understood as a human-only affair. New research suggests that isn’t so.
content: Can a mouse learn a new song?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Does Hip-Hop Mean to You?
description: The 50th anniversary of hip-hop’s origin is being celebrated this year: What songs, artists, lyrics and moments from its first five decades stand out to you?
content: On Aug. 11, 1973, DJ Kool Herc threw a back-to-school party at 1520 Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx and mixed two records into a continuous breakbeat. That day is now widely recognized as the birth of hip-hop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: James Dolan Doesn’t Like ‘Owning Teams.’ His New Project: A Sphere.
description: Mr. Dolan, who controls the company that owns the Knicks and the Rangers, is set to open a behemoth arena in Las Vegas that he hopes will revolutionize live entertainment. Back home in New York, he is facing the wrath of lawyers, politicians and sports fans.
content: In his 26th-floor office, high above Midtown Manhattan, James L. Dolan sits on a white couch by a large desk and armoire decorated with family photographs, with an electric guitar on a stand in the corner. His eyes are trained on a wall-mounted surveillance screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Visits Iowa, Aiming to Halt Rivals by Stepping Up Appearances
description: After a light campaign schedule in the key early state, the former president and his allies are now taking steps to lock up his support there.
content: Even as former President Donald J. Trump faces a crowded field of Republican primary challengers, he has kept a relatively light campaign schedule, particularly in Iowa, the first state to hold a 2024 nominating contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: U.S. Will Resume Offering Free At-Home Covid Tests
description: The Biden administration is restarting a program that has provided hundreds of millions of free tests through the Postal Service.
content: The Biden administration, looking ahead to a possible winter surge of Covid-19, announced on Wednesday that it was reviving its program of offering Americans free coronavirus tests through the mail and would spend $600 million to buy tests from a dozen domestic manufacturers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Beloved Banyan Tree That Burned in Lahaina Fires Shows Signs of Recovery
description: The 150-year-old tree was badly burned in the fires that ravaged Maui last month. New green leaves hint at the possibility of recovery for the tree and its community.
content: Over the decades, residents have gathered, feasted and proposed marriage beneath the 150-year-old banyan tree in the downtown area of Lahaina, Hawaii. But last month, after a fast-moving blaze tore through the town in West Maui, scorching the tree, some feared that it might not live on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Google’s Bard Just Got More Powerful. It’s Still Erratic.
description: The chatbot now pulls information from a user’s Gmail, Google Docs and Google Drive accounts. The feature leaves a lot to be desired.
content: This week, Bard — Google’s competitor to ChatGPT — got an upgrade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Solomon
title: Heading Upstairs With Roy Lichtenstein
description: “Bauhaus Stairway Mural: The Large Version,” created by the artist for a Beverly Hills building, was rejected by its new tenant. It’s New York’s temporary gain.
content: With the 100th birthday of Roy Lichtenstein approaching on Oct. 27, can we please turn our attention to the meaning of the word “forever?” Art is long and life is short, the maxim goes, but now even the new Lichtenstein stamps issued by the U.S. Postal Service for the artist’s centennial come with the promise of “Forever.” Conversely, one of the artist’s best-known works, the jumbo-size “Bauhaus Stairway Mural: The Large Version,” has been removed from its supposedly permanent digs in Beverly Hills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and Kayla Guo
title: Senate Confirms Chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, Sidestepping Tuberville Blockade
description: The Senate backed Gen. Charles Q. Brown Jr. of the Air Force for chairman and planned to advance promotions of two other military officials blockaded by Senator Tommy Tuberville of Alabama.
content: The Senate confirmed Gen. Charles Q. Brown Jr. of the Air Force on Wednesday as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, circumventing Senator Tommy Tuberville’s blockade of Pentagon promotions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Gas Prices Have Crept Higher This Summer, a Challenge for the Fed
description: Now at their highest level in 11 months, they can complicate the Federal Reserve’s campaign to rein in inflation.
content: Your eyes are not deceiving you: Gas prices are rising yet again. On Wednesday, the national average for unleaded gasoline was $3.88 per gallon, according to AAA, the highest level in nearly a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘Why Rappers Stopped Writing: The Punch-In Method’
description: Fifty years into hip-hop’s constant evolution, many of today’s rappers don’t write down their lyrics at all. What goes into creating a rap song now?
content: Have you ever dreamed of being a rapper? Have you ever tried your hand at the craft? What do you think it takes to create a rap song today?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Hope at the Bottom of the ‘Child Care Cliff’
description: Demographic factors draining Social Security may force Congress to act to sustain our broken child care system.
content: I had a fantasy that after the child care disaster of the past couple of years, there might be a more permanent, federal-level change in financial support for the sector. It did feel, for a little while, as if politicians were finally paying attention to the decades-long problem. In September 2021, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said “Child care is a textbook example of a broken market,” one that really isn’t working for caregivers, parents or children. That year, Congress passed the American Rescue Plan Act, which provided funding to help stabilize the child care market, which at the time was in something of a free fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: At the Intersection of Art and Science Stands Tomás Saraceno
description: The artist speaks about his love of spiders, the flip side of sustainability and more.
content: Spiders are usually unwelcome at an art exhibition: They are hastily removed, along with their webs, to avoid scaring visitors and giving an impression of filth. Yet they are the centerpiece of Tomás Saraceno’s art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Michigan and the Auto Industry Share a Past. What About the Future?
description: Fewer Michigan residents work in auto manufacturing than before, but a strike by U.A.W. members is a reminder of what the industry still means to the state.
content: Michigan’s economy and identity have been intertwined with auto manufacturing since Henry Ford perfected the moving assembly line and made Detroit a magnet for blue-collar workers seeking a middle-class foothold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: ‘A Perfect Storm for the Ambitious, Extreme Ideologue’
description: Is there something unique to the United States that exacerbates partisan animosity, even in good times?
content: Economic conditions are improving at a much faster rate in the United States than they are in Europe, but partisan polarization is worsening here at a more intense pace than elsewhere. What gives?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Miriam Jordan
title: Unlawful Border Crossings Are Rising Fast After a Brief Decline
description: Migrants and advocates say that some people who have been waiting months for the opportunity to enter the U.S. legally have grown impatient and are willing to take a risk.
content: Unlawful crossings along the Southern border have reached levels not seen for several months, straining government resources and taxing some local communities where large numbers of migrants have been released from federal custody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Will Republicans Abandon This Medical Triumph?
description: In 2003, President Bush started PEPFAR to fight AIDS. But after saving 25 million lives, its future is in doubt.
content: Twenty years ago, the Republican Party started what may have been the most lifesaving government initiative in modern history. It turned the tide of AIDS around the world and has saved 25 million lives so far — equivalent to the entire population of Australia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 20, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Sept. 20, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about a meeting between the Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Elon Musk misidentified the location of the meeting. The two met at a Tesla factory, not the Tesla headquarters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Ice Spice’s Munchkin Drink + Jann Wenner Backlash
description: Plus: what it’s like in Sean Combs’s sauna.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Jango Edwards, Clown Who Challenged His Art Form, Dies at 73
description: More Frank Zappa than Ronald McDonald, he moved the field beyond red noses, infusing it with social commentary while breaking down walls of propriety.
content: Jango Edwards may have been the most famous clown never to don a red nose. In fact he was as far from the family-friendly Bozo as one can imagine: rude, scatological, raunchy. He performed in drag, in fat suits and sometimes in nothing at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: At Sports Stadiums, Reducing Waste Is a Team Effort
description: Leagues, teams and stadiums are working to embrace sustainable practices, fight the effects of climate change and inspire fans to do the same.
content: The Resource Recovery Room beneath Mercedes-Benz Stadium was humming with activity one afternoon last month. Workers fed food into a compactor for compostable material, aluminum cans into another compactor and tossed other items into a variety of recycling bins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa and Noah Weiland
title: The Reach of Wildfire Smoke Is Going Global and Undoing Progress on Clean Air
description: In the United States, smoke from wildfires is undoing progress from the Clean Air Act. In poorer countries, the situation is even worse.
content: On the heels of an exceptionally fiery and smoky summer, two new reports released Wednesday confirmed what many Americans have been already seeing and breathing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Attia
title: Adults Are Panicked About Teens and Social Media. These Girls Have Advice.
description: Parents and public health experts have a lot to say about what adolescent girls do on their phones. We asked teens to weigh in.
content: Psychologists suggest teenagers take social media breaks, and ask themselves as they scroll: “Do I feel bad about myself while looking at this?” Public health experts recommend “adult monitoring” and setting clear boundaries for when and where teens have access to their phones. The surgeon general wants parents to keep their child’s bedroom device-free for at least an hour before bedtime, and through the night. In Utah, lawmakers have determined that kids under 18 should not have access to TikTok or Instagram without parental permission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Mohn
title: To Help Cyclists, and the Environment, This Tool Looks for Crashes
description: An international pilot program is helping cities to identify and pinpoint high risk locations where cyclists and light-mobility users are likely to have collisions.
content: Over 20 years, Fayetteville, Ark., steadily built a 110-mile bicycle network of paved and natural-surface trails that today weaves through the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘Fear and Desire’: Kubrick’s First War
description: Stanley Kubrick’s called his first feature, which is getting a new run at Metrograph, “boring and pretentious.” Instead, it is a revelation.
content: Seen in retrospect, a first feature by a major filmmaker can be a revelation particularly if, as with Stanley Kubrick’s low-budget war movie “Fear and Desire,” it concerns a career-long preoccupation — and even more so if the filmmaker has attempted to suppress it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: What Fed Rate Moves Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
description: Savers benefit from higher rates, but borrowers have faced bigger bills on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
content: Policymakers at the Federal Reserve will announce their latest decision on interest rates on Wednesday, after a series of increases squeezed the budgets of debt-laden Americans and rewarded those with money to stash in savings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: In Large and Small Ways, These Leaders Are Taking On Climate Change
description: The New York Times Climate Forward event will include speakers who are working on everything from new grain technologies to protecting native species.
content: The New York Times Climate Forward event on Thursday will feature distinguished speakers and panelists addressing the challenge of lowering carbon emissions. But in between the onstage presentations, participants also will have the opportunity to engage in small groups with some of the people who are on the front lines of efforts to thwart climate change. They range from a youth leader who helped organize a large-scale march at the United Nations to a waste expert whose videos about trash have gone viral on TikTok. Here are profiles of a few.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: DeSantis Slams Biden Climate Policy: ‘An Agenda to Control You’
description: The Florida governor delivered an address in Texas that favored oil and gas development over climate agreements and electric vehicles.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Wednesday unveiled an energy plan in the heart of oil country, criticizing electric vehicles and global climate agreements, promising lower fuel prices and pushing for more oil and gas development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Is My Mother Obsessed With Buying Me a Status Bag?
description: A reader who is uncomfortable with expensive gifts doesn’t know how to respond to a $7,000 handbag she had begged her mother not to send.
content: My mom has wanted to buy me a luxury bag for a few years, but I have reservations about spending lots of money on things. Still, when she asked for my opinion about a bag for herself, I provided one — though I suspected it was really for me. I texted her that I appreciate everything she does, but I asked her not to buy me a bag. (Having expensive things makes me anxious.) She agreed, but then she sent me more pictures of status bags. I repeated my request. Then I spoke to my sibling, who convinced me that gifts are my mom’s way of expressing love, and that she can afford it. (She’s also having a hard time now caring for my grandfather.) So, I prepared myself to receive a $2,000 bag. But the one that arrived cost $7,000 — which stresses me out! I love my mom, but she didn’t respect my feelings. How can I handle this nicely?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Ephrat Livni
title: How $100 Oil Could Scramble the Fed’s Fight Against Inflation
description: Goldman Sachs and others are predicting that crude will hit triple-digit prices, a scenario that could impact global economic growth.
content: Crude oil has slipped below the 10-month high it hit on Tuesday. But analysts say the monthslong rally that has sent prices close to $100 a barrel isn’t over, posing a big risk for global growth and complicating central bankers’ efforts to tame inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: As a National Favorite Fumbles, New Zealand Falls for Another Rugby Team
description: An improbable run by the New Zealand Warriors has offered some excitement to counter the All Blacks’ recent misfortune.
content: The New Zealand fan was despondent. He had just witnessed history in Paris, where rugby’s greatest team, the All Blacks of New Zealand, had suffered its first loss in the group stages of the World Cup. But when asked if he had a message for his compatriots back home, he looked into the TV camera, grinned and cheered: “Up the Wahs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Sea Dogs
description: Gina Turner makes her New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: ‘Really? Prince William?’ New Yorkers Stumbled Into a Chance Royal Encounter.
description: In New York, a crowd draws a crowd, but when the prince showed up, at least one passer-by was “awe-struck.”
content: In New York, nothing draws a crowd like a crowd. Sidney Giustra has lived a block south of the World Trade Center for 17 years, long enough to know when somebody famous is about to arrive. She has gone outside to find Robert De Niro, George W. Bush, Joe Biden and Andrew Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: How Well Do You Get Along With Your Siblings?
description: What is the greatest gift you have gained from them?
content: Do you have siblings? Would you say you are close to them? Or, are your relationships often difficult or strained?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A New Dispute Arises Over a 15-Year-Old Formula 1 Title
description: Comments by the former head of Formula 1 have prompted Felipe Massa to ask that he be awarded a title he just missed out on.
content: Felipe Massa, the Brazilian racing driver, believes he lost the Formula 1 championship unfairly, and now he plans to ask a British court to have the result overturned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai and Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Assassination Claim Further Divides Its Indian Diaspora
description: The charge that the Indian government is linked to the killing of a Sikh separatist may fuel the rift between Canada’s Sikhs and Hindus.
content: The stunning allegation that India was behind the assassination of a Sikh separatist leader in British Columbia has revived long-simmering tensions within Canada’s Indian diaspora, pitting staunch Hindu nationalists against supporters of the creation of an independent Sikh state called Khalistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Doug Burgum and Asa Hutchinson May Miss the Cut for the Next G.O.P. Debate
description: Low poll numbers could keep the long-shot Republicans off the stage next Wednesday in the second presidential primary debate.
content: After eking their way into the first Republican presidential debate last month, Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota and former Arkansas Gov. Asa Hutchinson, long-shot candidates, appear to be in jeopardy of failing to qualify for the party’s second debate next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Connie Chang
title: When Your Workout Stops Working
description: Fitness progress can stall. Here’s how to get over the hump.
content: The first weeks of a new exercise routine can be hard — your muscles tremble, your lungs burn, your heart races. But after a month or two, it gets easier: You’re running faster and longer, or lifting weights with more ease. Then suddenly, progress slows or stalls. You’ve hit a workout plateau.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: What We Know About Canada’s Claims Against India About a Sikh’s Killing
description: A separatist leader’s death in British Columbia has strained already tense ties between the two nations.
content: On Monday, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada made the shocking accusation that government agents from India had been involved in the killing of a Sikh community leader in British Columbia in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $400,000 Homes in Indiana, Virginia and New York
description: A Cape Cod-style house in Indianapolis, a Colonial Revival home in Richmond and a Craftsman bungalow in Saugerties.
content: This property is on a tree-lined street abutting Broad Ripple Park; the backyard gate opens into the park, where walking trails offer views of the White River. It is a few blocks from the small businesses, restaurants and big-box retailers on Broad Ripple Avenue, and from a shopping center with a Target and a Lowe’s. A Saturday-morning farmers’ market that operates year-round is about a mile away. Broad Ripple High School is a five-minute drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Tiffany Hsu
title: ChatGPT Can Now Generate Images, Too
description: OpenAI released a new version of its DALL-E image generator to a small group of testers and incorporated the technology into its popular ChatGPT chatbot.
content: ChatGPT can now generate images — and they are shockingly detailed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Carole Rothman to End 45-Year Tenure at Second Stage Theater
description: The nonprofit, a singular institution in New York’s theatrical ecosystem, has presented acclaimed works like “Between Riverside and Crazy” and “Next to Normal.”
content: Carole Rothman, the president and artistic director of Second Stage Theater, will step down next spring after 45 years with the organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Abortion Comments Expose a Line of Attack for Rivals in Iowa
description: After Donald Trump said a six-week ban signed by Ron DeSantis in Florida was “a terrible thing,” Iowa’s governor defended a similar law in her state, and others joined in the criticism.
content: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa attacked former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday for his criticism of restrictive abortion legislation, highlighting a potential weakness for Mr. Trump in her state just months before the Iowa caucuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Sufjan Stevens Says He Lost Ability to Walk From Guillain-Barré Syndrome
description: The indie-rock singer-songwriter said in a statement on his website that he was expected to recover from the rare neurological condition.
content: Sufjan Stevens, the indie-rock singer-songwriter, said in a statement on his website on Wednesday that he was in recovery from a rare neurological condition called Guillain-Barré syndrome that had taken away his ability to walk, saying he had been hospitalized for several weeks but was expected to recover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Thursday Briefing: Climate and Ukraine at the U.N.
description: Plus how rap is written today.
content: The U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, convened a special summit yesterday in New York designed to shine a spotlight on the most ambitious global leaders on climate policy. The leaders of the U.S. and China, the world’s biggest polluters, did not get a turn at the microphone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Foreign Exchange: Get the Best Rate
description: How to avoid foreign transaction and bank fees, and where to get the best rate when you travel abroad.
content: Using foreign money wisely requires understanding the going exchange rate with the U. S. dollar and practicing the following strategies to avoid excessive fees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1923: Britain Frowns on Rum Running Stock Scheme
description: Prohibitionists pushed for the British authorities to investigate organizations promoting the export of alcohol to the United States.
content: LONDON, Wednesday. — British authorities and prohibition elements rallying under the banner of the United Kingdom Alliance, one of the strongest dry organizations here, are waiting to swoop down on the next promoter who attempts to capitalize America’s thirst as an investment scheme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: A Chile Paste So Good, It’s Protected by the U.N.
description: Real-deal Tunisian harissa is an anchor to the motherland and a bright, specific accent to countless dishes.
content: Last year, UNESCO officially deemed harissa, the brick red, aromatic chile paste, “an integral part of domestic provisions and the daily culinary and food traditions of Tunisian society.” Keyword: Tunisian.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can Civics Lessons for the Young Help Mend Society?
description: Readers react to a guest essay by educators at Stanford. Also: The new Senate dress code; Ron DeSantis and vaccines.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: McCarthy Declines to Host House Forum for Zelensky Amid G.O.P. Rifts
description: The speaker plans a private meeting with the Ukrainian president, but his refusal to arrange for rank-and-file lawmakers to hear from him directly reflects Republican resistance to continuing aid to Kyiv.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy, facing a right-wing rebellion in his ranks and mounting G.O.P. resistance to aiding Ukraine, has declined to convene a forum for President Volodymyr Zelensky to address members of the House on Thursday during a visit to Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Astronaut Ready for Silence After Record-Setting Full Year in Space
description: Last week, Frank Rubio broke the record for the longest continuous spaceflight by a U.S. astronaut. He was supposed to be away for only six months.
content: After a year spent listening to the constant hum of the complicated machinery that keeps the International Space Station livable, the astronaut Frank Rubio is looking forward to some silence on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Franzen, Grisham and Other Prominent Authors Sue OpenAI
description: The suit, filed with the Authors Guild, accuses the A.I. company of infringing on authors’ copyrights, claiming it used their books to train its ChatGPT chatbot.
content: A group of prominent novelists, including John Grisham, Jonathan Franzen and Elin Hilderbrand, are joining the legal battle against OpenAI over its chatbot technology, as fears about the encroachment of artificial intelligence on creative industries continue to grow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: When Being Good Is Just a Matter of Being Lucky
description: The concept of “moral luck” challenges assumptions about how to assess blame.
content: The punishment for murder is more severe than the punishment for attempted murder. But it’s not completely obvious why. The person who tried to kill but failed is just as bad a person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Garland Rebuffs Republicans’ Efforts to Reveal Details on Hunter Biden Inquiry
description: The soft-spoken attorney general struck a sharper tone during testimony before the Judiciary Committee, saying prosecutors won’t be “intimidated” by threats from Trump allies.
content: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland offered a fiery defense of the Justice Department’s investigation of Hunter Biden on Wednesday, telling a House committee he was “not Congress’s prosecutor” — and would not reveal details of the inquiry no matter how much pressure lawmakers applied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg and Graham Bowley
title: Schiele Artworks Returned to Heirs of Owner Killed by Nazis
description: The Manhattan district attorney’s office arranged for the return of seven works to a family that has been seeking them for more than a quarter of a century.
content: Seven works by the Austrian Expressionist Egon Schiele were handed over on Wednesday to the heirs of the Viennese cabaret artist who had owned them before he was murdered by the Nazis, marking a major turning point in one of the art world’s longest-running Holocaust restitution cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nell Gallogly
title: Looking to Space in the Race to Decarbonize
description: Space-based solar power, once a topic for science fiction, is gaining interest.
content: Ali Hajimiri thinks there’s a better way to power the planet — one that’s not getting the attention it deserves. The Caltech professor of electrical engineering envisages thousands of solar panels floating in space, unobstructed by clouds and unhindered by day-night cycles, wirelessly transmitting massive amounts of energy to receivers on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Another Dose of Delight From a Writer Who Finds Wonder in His Backyard
description: In ‘The Book of (More) Delights,’ Ross Gay offers a joyful approach to gardening, with gratitude even for the dandelions.
content: Yes, please. I’ll have another dose of delight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Wanted: 20,000 Young Americans to Fight Climate Change
description: The White House plans to create an “American Climate Corps” that would train thousands of young people for green jobs.
content: President Biden intends to use executive authority to train and employ thousands of young people in jobs to fight global warming, Ali Zaidi, the White House national climate adviser, said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘No Pen, No Pad’: The Unlikely Way Rap Is Written Today
description: Fifty years into hip-hop’s constant evolution, many of today’s rappers don’t write down their lyrics at all. Here’s how they make songs now.
content: Picture a rapper writing a song — but now forget about the pen and paper. In fact, in a recording studio these days, there may be no actual writing happening at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Portraits of Fire Victims: Two Toddlers Named ‘Memory,’ and a Teacher About to Wed
description: A picture is emerging of some of the 77 people who died when the derelict building in Johannesburg where they were living went up in flames on Aug. 31.
content: As many as 600 people called the squalid five-story building at 80 Albert Street in downtown Johannesburg home. Nearly three weeks after a fire tore through the building, leaving at least 77 people dead, survivors recall those they lost and the workaday family lives they led inside a trash-strewn building that had no heat, and little water or electricity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The Beach Is Lovely. The Water, Maybe Not So Much.
description: As oceans warm, pathogenic bacteria are turning up more frequently in northern regions, scientists say.
content: On a warm day in early July, Ed Houlihan guided kayakers on a four-mile trip on Cape Cod from Popponesset Bay up the Mashpee River to a freshwater pond. It was three hours of paddling round trip, but afterward Mr. Houlihan, 83, felt no worse for wear — at first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Will Hurd Releases A.I. Plan, a First in the Republican Presidential Field
description: The former Texas congressman’s plan takes an expansive view of both the potential and the risks of artificial intelligence, calling for it to be used more widely but also tightly regulated.
content: The policy plan on artificial intelligence released by former Representative Will Hurd of Texas on Wednesday makes him the first candidate in the Republican presidential field to formally propose a way to navigate the uses and dangers of a technology so thorny he likened it to nuclear fission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Paul Robeson’ Review: A Tribute to an Entertainment Titan
description: The film’s subtitle is drawn from one of the performer’s quotes in his autobiography “Here I Stand”: “I’m a Negro. I’m an American.”
content: The opening of “Paul Robeson: ‘I’m a Negro. I’m an American.’” offers an unintentional caveat about the 1989 documentary directed by the East German filmmaker Kurt Tetzlaff. Paul Robeson’s rich baritone undergirds archival footage of Black children playing in a dusty open space, smokestacks in the background. The use by the director of a Negro spiritual, however beautiful, swaps whatever joy these kids might have been experiencing (they are at play after all) for a questionable sentimentality around Black life and suffering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Annie Karni
title: Republicans Inch Closer to Spending Deal, Spoiling for a Shutdown Showdown
description: Speaker Kevin McCarthy, grasping for G.O.P. votes to bring spending bills up for debate, proposed a new measure with deeper cuts to appease the hard right, paving the way for a clash with the Senate.
content: House Republicans inched closer on Wednesday to overcoming deep internal divisions and reaching an agreement that would allow them to advance stalled spending legislation, as Speaker Kevin McCarthy bowed to the demands of far-right lawmakers for steep spending cuts that stood little chance of surviving in the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Grant
title: The SATs Will Be Different Next Year, and That Could Be a Game-Changer
description: Exams that test speed favor the fastest sprinters, but life is a marathon.
content: A few years ago, I started asking lecture halls filled with students to raise their hands if they had run out of time on the SAT. In each room, nearly every hand went up. I was surprised, but I shouldn’t have been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Unions Fight in the States to Make Biden’s Climate Agenda Work for Workers
description: Labor leaders worry that some federal incentives for renewable energy do not come with strict standards on pay. In Maine, they added their own.
content: President Biden’s labor and environmental goals are colliding in the auto industry, where concerns over the electric vehicle transition underpin an autoworkers strike. But in states like Maine, unions and environmental groups have teamed up in an attempt to make a central promise of the president’s green agenda come true for workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: She Pioneered Internet Fame, He Helped Draft a Constitution. Now They’re in Love.
description: Who would have guessed that the former New York media obsession Julia Allison and the law scholar Noah Feldman would make a great couple?
content: One afternoon in May 2020, Julia Allison sat in a hot spring near Joshua Tree National Park, crying. A media strategist and tech-world socialite — who in her former life as a New York City journalist and media personality pioneered the sort of internet-driven microfame that we now call “influencing” — Ms. Allison was going through yet another breakup. She wanted to know: What was the point of it all?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tatiana Schlossberg
title: The Importance of Protecting Ocean Life
description: The head of the Wildlife Conservation Society makes a case for the High Seas Treaty, which would protect ocean biodiversity and more.
content: When delegates from countries around the world meet this week at the United Nations, they will begin to ratify a landmark agreement for environmental conservation, climate-change mitigation and biodiversity protection that is known as the High Seas Treaty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Schubert at the Vast Park Avenue Armory: Intimate, Lonely, Exposed
description: The tenor Jonas Kaufmann stars in “Doppelganger,” a staging of “Schwanengesang” by Claus Guth, making his New York debut.
content: In Schubert’s song “Der Doppelgänger,” a piano resounds with increasingly tormented chords as the narrator recounts a realization: that a pained stranger, wringing his hands in the night, is in fact himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Air Quality Reaches Unhealthy Levels in Bay Area After Wildfires
description: Smoke from northwestern California and southwestern Oregon has blown over from the Bay Area and is expected to linger until Thursday.
content: Bay Area and Northern California residents woke up to air quality rated as “unhealthy for some” on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Our Techno Future Is Here: A.I.-Scripted Stories Take the Stage
description: “Prometheus Firebringer” and “Bioadapted” test the waters, while the abstract “Psychic Self Defense” is a warm and pulsing counterpoint.
content: Seated behind a plain wooden table, the theater maker Annie Dorsen is not costumed to catch our gaze, or lit dramatically. In the performance-lecture that is her A.I.-focused show “Prometheus Firebringer,” at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn, you might assume she’d be the boring part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: Spain Women’s Soccer Team Agrees to Play After Talks
description: Players’ participation had been in doubt after many signed a letter demanding an overhaul of the Spanish soccer federation in the wake of sexism scandals.
content: Nearly a month after Spain’s World Cup-winning women’s national soccer team was thrown into turmoil over a forcible kiss, the players have agreed to come back and play their scheduled high-profile matches in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suleman Anaya and Fabian Martinez
title: In These Houses, It’s What’s Outside That Counts
description: Throughout Mexico, the veteran architect Alberto Kalach creates spare dwellings that respond to the landscape around them.
content: IT’S BEST TO arrive at Casa Valle, the home the Mexican architect Alberto Kalach designed for his family in 1996, at night, when darkness heightens its mystery. Past a wooden gate in Valle de Bravo, a lakeside town two hours west of Mexico City, a narrow path along a brick wall leads to a dim, cell-like vestibule that all but eliminates the world beyond. From here, you can enter a 43-foot-high tower containing four bedrooms or turn right into the living area and garden: This common gathering space, entirely open on one side to the elements, would appear to be the home’s most arresting feature, until you climb a stairway at its far end. On the roof, a 28½-foot travertine bench is installed along one side of a long pool that’s horizontally bisected by five thick concrete walls; Kalach, 63, calls the resulting interstices “cubicles.” They’re intended to provide privacy as well as shade, creating meditative spots where, come daybreak, you can gaze out over the green valley extending far past the property’s limits.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: From Flood-Struck Ruins, Libyans Demand Official Accountability
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 20, 2023.
content: “Which of the successive governments which have come to power would you hold accountable for this, especially when you have fragmented governments?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: 8 Ways to Teach and Learn About Hip-Hop
description: It’s the 50th anniversary of hip-hop. To celebrate, we invite students to explore its remarkable rise, its remaking of the global cultural landscape, and its legacy and future.
content: Over five decades, hip-hop has grown from a new art form to a culture-defining superpower. At first dismissed as a fad, often derided as a nuisance or a menace, hip-hop has become a multibillion-dollar industry and a global juggernaut — woven into nearly every corner of American life. Jon Caramanica, a New York Times music critic, writes:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
title: Ray Epps, Target of Conspiracy Theory, Pleads Guilty to Jan. 6 Misdemeanor
description: Prosecutors said he had never worked as an agent of the government, again refuting a right-wing theory that he helped instigate the Capitol riot in a federal plot to discredit Trump supporters.
content: Ray Epps, the Trump supporter who was swept up in one of the most persistent right-wing conspiracy theories connected to the events of Jan. 6, 2021, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to a single misdemeanor charge for his role in the attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Gabler, Steve Eder and Allie Pitchon
title: A Top New York Hospital, an Unapproved Treatment and an F.D.A. Warning
description: A product made from umbilical cord blood was used in spine surgeries at a Manhattan hospital. After a federal warning came an internal complaint: Patients should have been told.
content: A visiting researcher at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center was startled when he read the warning from the Food and Drug Administration about a product that had been used in spine surgeries at the esteemed Manhattan hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Pro-Choice? Pro-Union? Donald Trump Has a Deal for You.
description: Why a general-election sales pitch might not hurt the front-runner in the primaries.
content: As Ron DeSantis’s challenge to Donald Trump has seemed to wither on the vine, a piece of conventional wisdom has hardened: That DeSantis has been offering Republican voters Trumpism without the drama, but now we know Republicans love the drama, indeed they can’t live without the drama, and mere substance simply leaves them cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Cotsifas
title: Cozy Accessories for Colder Weather
description: Bags and shoes in cushy shearling, plush and faux fur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Magician of Milan
description: Wait … what is that? Is it denim? Is it flannel? No, it’s leather. How Matthieu Blazy changed Bottega Veneta and our material expectations.
content: For years, Matthieu Blazy was a fashion ghost: a specter whispered about but rarely seen. “The most famous designer you’ve never heard of,” New York magazine crowed in 2014.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Can We Put a Price on Climate Damages?
description: A new model finds a remarkable tally for the impact of even a bit of carbon over decades.
content: There is nothing the modern world sees more clearly than a dollar figure. But whenever anyone tries to put an actual price on the damages from global warming — to calibrate a carbon tax, assess past responsibility or aid in litigation against fossil-fuel malefactors — the numbers are almost too much to process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samer Attar
title: I’m an American Doctor. Here’s Why I Treat the Wounded Far From Home.
description: Work in a war zone is meaningful, but it can take a heavy psychic toll.
content: “I’ve still got my head on my shoulders,” the Ukrainian soldier told me shortly before I operated on him. “I’ll be all right.” He had volunteered to defuse mines, and a Russian drone had dropped a bomb over his position. The blast had obliterated one of his legs below the knee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Zelensky Speaks to the U.N., and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Judge Rejects Hunter Biden’s Request for Remote Arraignment
description: The president’s son will make his first court appearance on three gun charges next week. His lawyer has said he will plead not guilty.
content: A judge in Delaware on Wednesday rejected a request by the president’s son, Hunter Biden, to make his first court appearance remotely, scheduling his arraignment on three gun charges for next week at the federal courthouse in Wilmington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: harried
description: This word has appeared in 66 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word harried has appeared in 66 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 6 in “3 Easy Dishes, One Near-Effortless Summer Dinner Party” by David Tanis:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: We Asked Readers to Spend the Summer Watching Birds. Here’s What Happened.
description: Thousands of people from around the world responded to the invitation, sharing their sightings with scientists at the Cornell Lab of Ornithology.
content: One Saturday morning in June, Amy Simmons spotted some sparrows flitting around a coastal marsh in Maine. She and her two companions, all dedicated bird-watchers, quickly identified one of the foraging birds as a Nelson’s sparrow, a small, round bird with a yellow stripe over its eye. Then, overhead, they spotted something slightly different. The stripe over this sparrow’s eye had a more saturated, orange tint, and its breast was speckled with black and white.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Covid Can Disrupt Your Sleep
description: Here’s why, and how to find some relief.
content: At this point, many of us recognize the hallmark symptoms of a Covid infection: an aching throat, a clogged nose, a persistent cough and an overwhelming sense of blah. But lying awake at night, during the peak of sickness or in the weeks or months following an infection, some people discover another downside: They can’t sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde Haberman
title: James Hoge, Who Led Two Big City Tabloids, Dies at 87
description: He was publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times, where he was also the top editor, and New York’s Daily News. He was later editor of Foreign Affairs magazine.
content: James Hoge, who was a blue-blooded editor and publisher of blue-collar newspapers in Chicago and New York for a quarter-century and then long guided a leading journal on international relations, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: How to Change Your Mind-Set About Aging
description: People who think positively about getting older often live longer, healthier lives. Here is how to reconsider your perspective.
content: At a pool party this summer, Johnnie Cooper climbed onto the diving board, executed a perfect dive and then joined a raucous game of Marco Polo. The occasion? Her 90th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Fed Pauses Rates
description: Also, the attorney general was grilled by House Republicans. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged today, a reflection of cooling inflation and a decision designed to give them more time to assess their next step. At the same time, they hinted that another rate hike would arrive later this year and projected that interest rates would remain high for longer than they had previously expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: How A.I. Increased the Graduation Rate at John Jay College by 32 Points
description: Software identified at-risk students, who were given extra help. Also, New London, Conn., hasn’t forgotten the traitor Benedict Arnold, 242 years later.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at software that lifted the senior graduation rate at John Jay College to 86 percent. We’ll also find out where the Revolutionary War traitor Benedict Arnold has not been forgotten — or forgiven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Defense Department Awards Chip Funding to Fuel Domestic Research
description: The $238 million in grants will set up eight research hubs, as a small slice of the federal money that will go to chip companies and research facilities in the coming months.
content: The Biden administration on Wednesday announced that it was awarding $238 million through the Defense Department to set up eight hubs around the United States for promoting innovation in the semiconductor industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Hill
title: A Boat Brings Books and Comfort to Isolated Villages Along Norway’s Coast
description: After decades of navigating Norway’s intricately carved fjords to bring books to isolated residents, the Epos’ funding was cut. Supporters came together to save the boat, and its mission.
content: After decades of navigating Norway’s intricately carved fjords to bring books to isolated residents, the Epos’ funding was cut. Supporters came together to save the boat, and its mission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ingrid Skjong
title: How to Clean a Yoga Mat
description: You'll need a spray bottle, some vinegar and elbow grease.
content: You'll need a spray bottle, some vinegar and elbow grease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Being 13
description: Three girls, one year. This is what it’s like to be 13 today, in a world that can’t stop talking about the dire state of your future.
content: Three girls, one year. This is what it’s like to be 13 today, in a world that can’t stop talking about the dire state of your future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Lauren Leatherby
title: Ukraine Has Gained Ground. But It Has Much Farther to Go
description: Ukraine’s counteroffensive has breached Russian defenses, but progress has been grueling and slow. Familiar obstacles, fresh troops and worsening weather lie ahead.
content: Ukraine’s counteroffensive has breached Russian defenses, but progress has been grueling and slow. Familiar obstacles, fresh troops and worsening weather lie ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden and Netanyahu Meet on Sidelines of U.N. General Assembly
description: The meeting between President Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at a New York City hotel, and not the White House, served as a reminder that their relationship remains thorny.
content: The meeting between President Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at a New York City hotel, and not the White House, served as a reminder that their relationship remains thorny.

author: By Noah Throop
title: Why Rappers Stopped Writing: The Punch-In Method
description: Fifty years into hip-hop’s constant evolution, many of today’s rappers don’t write down their lyrics at all. Here’s how they make songs now.
content: Fifty years into hip-hop’s constant evolution, many of today’s rappers don’t write down their lyrics at all. Here’s how they make songs now.

author: By The New York Times
title: Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged After Latest Meeting
description: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, said that the central bank would keep interest rates on hold, but stayed open to another increase this year.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, said that the central bank would keep interest rates on hold, but stayed open to another increase this year.
